articles.headline: China Confronts Mounting Piles of Unsold Goods
articles.snippet: The severity of the country’s inventory surplus has been masked by the blocking or adjusting of economic data by the government.
articles.abstract: The severity of the country’s inventory surplus has been masked by the blocking or adjusting of economic data by the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — After three decades of torrid growth, China is encountering an unfamiliar problem with its newly struggling economy: a huge buildup of unsold goods that is cluttering shop floors, clogging car dealerships and filling factory warehouses.

articles.headline: Facebook Reorients Itself for a Small-Screen World
articles.snippet: The company is trying to find ways to show lucrative ads to mobile users without cluttering up their hand-held screens and driving them away in frustration.
articles.abstract: The company is trying to find ways to show lucrative ads to mobile users without cluttering up their hand-held screens and driving them away in frustration.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — At Facebook’s headquarters here, mobile devices are everywhere. The first thing visitors do is sign in on iPads at the front desk. Employees at the campus coffee shop use iPads as cash registers. Instead of sending e-mails, Facebook employees prefer to use the company’s messaging system, which pops up new messages on both mobile devices and PCs.

articles.headline: Big Income Losses for Those Near Retirement
articles.snippet: Another reason, besides the housing bust, that those nearing retirement age may have suffered most from the financial crisis: a nearly 10 percent decline in household income in three years.
articles.abstract: Another reason, besides the housing bust, that those nearing retirement age may have suffered most from the financial crisis: a nearly 10 percent decline in household income in three years.

articles.headline: Bad Grades Are Rising for Auditors
articles.snippet: In a disturbing trend, more audits are failing quality reviews, and the problem isn’t limited to work done by small firms.
articles.abstract: In a disturbing trend, more audits are failing quality reviews, and the problem isn’t limited to work done by small firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are audits getting worse? Or are the inspectors getting pickier?

articles.headline: New York Fed Sells Off Last A.I.G.-Related Holdings
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said on Thursday that it had wound down the final remnant of its rescue of the American International Group, generating a multibillion-dollar profit in the process.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said on Thursday that it had wound down the final remnant of its rescue of the American International Group, generating a multibillion-dollar profit in the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: 8:31 p.m. | Updated The government is one step closer to shedding its burden from the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In Effort to Curb Money Market Funds, a Plan B Is Considered
articles.snippet: Government regulators are considering invoking powers that were granted by the Dodd-Frank law to improve oversight of the money market fund industry.
articles.abstract: Government regulators are considering invoking powers that were granted by the Dodd-Frank law to improve oversight of the money market fund industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the failure of one effort to overhaul a major part of the mutual fund industry, top government officials worked on Thursday to find alternative ways to rein in what they see as a systemic threat to the financial system.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Export Powerhouse Feels Pangs of Labor Strife
articles.snippet: As Bangladesh garment workers have seen their meager earnings eroded by double-digit inflation, protests and violent clashes with the police have become increasingly common.
articles.abstract: As Bangladesh garment workers have seen their meager earnings eroded by double-digit inflation, protests and violent clashes with the police have become increasingly common.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISHWARDI, Bangladesh — The air thickened with tear gas as police and paramilitary officers jogged into the Ishwardi Export Processing Zone firing rubber bullets and swinging cane poles. Panicked factory workers tried to flee. A seamstress crumpled to the ground, knocked unconscious by a shot in the head.

articles.headline: Giving Reins to the States Over Drilling
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney is proposing to end a century of federal control over oil and gas drilling and coal mining on government lands to court western voters and supporters from the energy industry.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney is proposing to end a century of federal control over oil and gas drilling and coal mining on government lands to court western voters and supporters from the energy industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: By proposing to end a century of federal control over oil and gas drilling and coal mining on government lands, Mitt Romney is making a bid for anti-Washington voters in key Western states while dangling the promise of a big reward to major campaign supporters from the energy industry.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: G.M. Has High Hopes for New, Smaller Cadillac
articles.snippet: Three years after General Motors hobbled out of bankruptcy, it is betting that the new Cadillac ATS will become a contender in the global luxury car market.
articles.abstract: Three years after General Motors hobbled out of bankruptcy, it is betting that the new Cadillac ATS will become a contender in the global luxury car market.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It has been three years since General Motors hobbled out of bankruptcy with a pledge that its newest cars would be competitive with the best in the world.

articles.headline: Signs Suggest Iran Is Speeding Up Work on Nuclear Program
articles.snippet: International nuclear inspectors will soon report that Iran has installed hundreds of new centrifuges in recent months and may also be speeding up production of nuclear fuel.
articles.abstract: International nuclear inspectors will soon report that Iran has installed hundreds of new centrifuges in recent months and may also be speeding up production of nuclear fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — International nuclear inspectors will soon report that Iran has installed hundreds of new centrifuges in recent months and may also be speeding up production of nuclear fuel while negotiations with the United States and its allies have ground to a near halt, according to diplomats and experts briefed on the findings.

articles.headline: Torrent of Syrian Refugees Strains Aid Effort and Region
articles.snippet: Many refugees are housed in schools, which will soon open, and camps that are not prepared for winter.
articles.abstract: Many refugees are housed in schools, which will soon open, and camps that are not prepared for winter.
articles.lead_paragraph: International relief agencies reported an alarming increase in Syrian refugees on Friday, shattering calculations made by the United Nations and spreading fears that the violence in Syria is creating a broader humanitarian crisis that could further destabilize the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Rick Gladstone and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Tax Credits Shed Light on Romney
articles.snippet: Some experts are looking at a corner of the tax code involving foreign tax credits, and pointing to intriguing clues buried in the returns Mitt Romney has released.
articles.abstract: Some experts are looking at a corner of the tax code involving foreign tax credits, and pointing to intriguing clues buried in the returns Mitt Romney has released.
articles.lead_paragraph: What doesn’t Mitt Romney want us to know?
